entry.title: Information Overload 2012-05-06
entry.content:
Because groups with wildly different perspectives dominate politics, the observation that ninety-nine per cent of Americans are being left behind economically isn’t of much use politically. The ninety-nine per cent is too big a category to be an effective political force.

Nicholas Lemann Evening the Odds

  • Mozilla Slams CISPA, Breaking Silicon Valley's Silence On Cybersecurity Bill
    Finally someone in the valley speaks out against CISPA.
  • Sanctions against Syria finding unintended targets
    Every time I read about sanctions against a country, they only seem to affect the wrong people.
  • The Google attack: How I attacked myself using Google Spreadsheets and I ramped up a $1000 bandwidth bill
    Very interesting read. In a previous company we started discussing the idea of "financial DoS" using AWS over 2 years ago.
  • Evening the Odds<brOn inequality in the US.
  • Roger Penrose Says Physics Is Wrong, From String Theory to Quantum Mechanics
    Interesting interview with Roger Penrose. I especially like the part about him and MC Escher.
  • Bad Boy aus gutem Hause
    An obituary for MCA by Der Spiegel (in German).
  • The Bo scandal: how we got that story
    Background info on how journalists uncovered the scandal around Bo Xilai.
  • When half a million Americans died and nobody noticed
    If this is true, this is a pretty bad pharmaceutical scandal.
  • Self-Awareness Matters: Finding Your Filters
    This sounds interesting, I may try that out.
  • Cheap help from Uganda
    US security firms in Iraq exploit workers from Uganda and other "third countries". Unless they are white.

entry.title: Information Overload 2012-04-29
entry.content:
You don't simply get to say you're not a racist; not being racist — or a sexist or a homophobe — is a constant, arduous process of unlearning, of being uncomfortable, of eating crow and being humbled and re-evaluating.

G.D. The Racist Harvard Law Student and Naming Names.

  • The Racist Harvard Law Student and Naming Names
    The quote above says it all.
  • Nazi-Vergleich zwingt Berliner Piraten zum Rückzug
    The German Pirate Party currently has problems dealing with rightwing views within their ranks.
  • 10 Things Science Says Will Make You Happy
    While there are no real surprises on this list, a lot of people — myself included — tend to forget some of the points mentioned in this article.
  • Liquid Constitution
    Island uses Liquid Democracy for rewriting the constitution (in German).
  • For Best Results, Forget the Bonus
    Why bonuses don't really work as motivation for employees.
  • Coolest jobs in tech (literally): running a South Pole data center
    Literally and figuratively this is a cool job indeed.
  • Is Psychology About to Come Undone?
    A researcher is trying to replicate resuls from studies published in various magazines to double check their results.

entry.title: Information Overload 2012-04-22
entry.content:
Economic development and social stability require freedom of expression, and an independent media to report on issues and abuses that government officials want to sweep under the rug.

Phil Robertson, deputy Asia director at Human Rights Watch Vietnam: Immediately Release Rights Bloggers

  • Silly Putty for Potholes
    A practical application for non-Newtonian fluids, great idea.
  • Avoiding The BlackBerry Blues: Know When To Fire Yourself
    More startup founders should read this.
  • Vietnam: Immediately Release Rights Bloggers
    Sometimes I wonder how much longer it will be before we see this kind of article about Europe...
  • Asia's Endangered Species: The Expat
    To quote the article, "Western companies must approach newly empowered Asian companies and consumers as equals and clients — not just manufacturing partners".
  • An Interview With Linus Torvalds
    I generally like interviews with Linux Torvals and this one is no exception.
  • It'll cost you
    How much would a Scottish independence cost and how will this influence the referendum in 2014?
  • SpaceX Given Green Light for First Launch to Space Station
    Soon the first commercial carrier will deliver cargo to the ISS.
  • How America Came To Torture Its Prisoners
    Don't blame this on some misguided individuals, this was planned from the top.
  • China: Crowdsourced Tax Enforcement
    Once again China comes up with a clever solution to a problem.
  • How do you like your meat?
    Interesting article on lab grown meat.

Would some kernel people prefer getting tucked in at night instead of being cursed at? I’m sure that would be appreciated. I don’t think I have it in me, though.

Linus Torvals An Interview With Linus Torvalds

entry.title: Information Overload 2012-04-15
entry.content:
• Corporate Rule of Cyberspace
    Philosopher Slavoj Žižek offers some thoughts on cloud computing. Some of the comments are interesting too.
  • A Robot Stole My Pulitzer!
    On automated journalism and the potential consequences for society.
  • A Forth Story...
    This long text from 1995 is not only interesting because it talks about Forth, but also because of the history of programming in the 70s, 80s and 90s.
  • Giving divorce a bad name
    South Sudan invaded an oil field in Sudan, which could lead to a fierce war. Make sure to read the comments too, there's some good stuff in there.
  • Code Not Physical Property, Court Rules in Goldman Sachs Espionage Case
    An update on the Aleynikov vs Goldman Sachs case.
  • Computer Scientists Build Computer Using Swarms of Crabs
    A computer exploiting the swarming behavior of soldier crabs. Ok, maybe just a function OR gate, but still rather cool.
  • Physicist Uses Math to Beat Traffic Ticket
    Who says math can't be useful in your daily life? ;-)
  • Rosen aus dem Beton
    About street gangs and gang related violence in Los Angeles (in German).
  • What Amazon's ebook strategy means
    Wether you agree with Charlie Stross or not, his posts are usually well written and provide food for thought.
  • Olympics 2012: branding 'police' to protect sponsors' exclusive rights
    Brave new corporate world.

entry.title: Information Overload 2012-04-08
entry.content:
Ich habe also mit meiner Aktion das alteingesessene Bild instituitionalisierter Brauchtums-Macht performativ dekonstruiert. Würde ich aus heutiger Sicht vielleicht sagen. Damals am Christkindlmarkt sagte ich nur “Esmeralda!” und humpelte wie Igor durch die Fleischberge an Touristen.

Markus Lust Auf LSD Am Christkindlmarkt

  • Not an April Fool
    An article by Charlie Stross on privacy in regard to social media, stalking apps and more.
  • Auf LSD am Christkindlmarkt
    Now that we all had sufficient time to get over Christmas, I can finally post this article by a Vice reporter who took some LSD before going to a Christmas market (in German).
  • Just how big are porn sites?
    Interesting, I always thought that from a system engineering/devops perspective it'd be very interesting to work for a porn site.
  • A Simple Commitment
    A potentially interesting idea regarding sexism in tech-related fields.
  • How Smart Is the Octopus?
    I often like articles on animal intelligence and this one is no exception.
  • The Best Birth Control In The World Is For Men
    This sounds very interesting.
  • What Cuba Can Teach Us About Food and Climate Change
    Forced by a lack of oil-based products, Cuba had to develop a form of agriculture that could prove useful to the rest of the world.
  • China Buys Inroads in the Caribbean, Catching U.S. Notice
    While the US are preoccupied elsewhere, China is making its presence felt in the Carribean.
  • 'War on drugs' has failed, say Latin American leaders
    Since Latin America suffers most from the war on drugs, it's about time that politicians there start exploring alternatives.
  • The Sahel falls apart
    Some background on the current situation in Mali.

It’s probably not unrealistic to say that porn makes up 30% of the total data transferred across the internet.

Sebastian Anthony Just How Big Are Porn Sites?
